Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Brian J. Stucky
Proposal Number: 1612335

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Brian Stucky is "Collections as repositories of natural history data: New tools, methods, and data to better understand the evolution of flesh fly parasitoids." The host institution for this fellowship is the University of Florida, and the sponsoring scientists are Robert Guralnick, Akito Kawahara, and Samuel Wong.

The goal of this research is to help unlock the potential of biological collections as repositories of natural history data by: 1) developing new methods for capturing life history data from collection specimens; 2) developing new software for phylogenetic comparative methods that provide a robust framework for analyzing these data; and 3) applying these new methods and software to a model phylogeny, the evolution of the parasitoid lifestyle in the highly diverse flesh flies (Diptera: Sarcophagidae). Phylogenetic comparative methods (PCMs) are important research tools of modern evolutionary biology because they can reveal the large-scale processes that create biological diversity - in other words, PCMs help us understand how evolution works. Effective use of PCMs requires detailed knowledge of species' natural history traits, yet for the most diverse groups of organisms, such as insects, such data are often unavailable. Biological collections contain extensive natural history information that could help address this data shortcoming, but new computational tools and research methods are needed to mobilize and exploit these data. Parasitoids - insects that feed parasitically as larvae but eventually kill their hosts - account for up to 25% of all insect species and are crucial for controlling agricultural pests, but relatively little is known about the evolution of their parasitoid lifestyle. The flesh flies are a large insect family that includes many parasitoid species of major economic, forensic, veterinary, and medical importance. The Fellow's research applies new data from multiple museum collections to improve understanding of parasitoid evolution and diversity. More broadly, the new analytical methods developed for by the Fellow will be applicable to a wide variety of evolutionary questions beyond this particular study.

The Fellow is being trained in laboratory and computational methods for capturing genetic and natural history data from collection specimens, statistical techniques for PCMs, and strategies for teaching and public outreach. Data and results from this project are being made freely available online, and all new software is open source. The Fellow's outreach activities include teaching university students about PCMs and collections data, mentoring undergraduates, and providing public educational programming about the diversity, biology, and value of flesh flies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of modern biology is to understand, on a grand scale, the forces that shape evolution and biodiversity.  Achieving this goal requires, among other things, detailed knowledge of how organisms are related to one another (i.e., their evolutionary history) and extensive data about their behavior, life history, and interactions with each other and with the environment (these kinds of information are often referred to as “natural history information”).  Recent years have seen an explosion in the quantity of available DNA sequencing data, which can reveal organisms’ evolutionary histories, and in the quantity of natural history information available from specimens in museum collections and from observations in nature.  Critically, we need data modeling tools and software that make it as easy as possible to compute with these data, especially as the scale of inquiry in biology continues to grow.  The main objective of this project was to make a substantial contribution to the development of these tools.  This work was focused in three areas.

First, I worked on developing new technologies for modeling and computing with insect natural history data.  Insects are extraordinarily diverse, and recording information about their natural histories in a computationally sophisticated manner is challenging.  One approach to solving this problem is to use a data modeling and reasoning framework called an “ontology”.  An ontology is a computational structure that provides a vocabulary for describing information.  The terms in a well-designed ontology are defined in a manner that allows a computer to understand them, which means that computers can do a certain amount of automated reasoning about data that are described using the ontology terms.  This is extremely useful when working with large quantities of heterogeneous information.  I organized a team of collaborators to work on the problem of developing an ontology for insect natural history data, and we made substantial progress toward this goal during the course of the project.  Ontology development is a complex task, and I also developed a sophisticated software package to aid in the process of developing, maintaining, and using ontologies.  This software product is freely available for anyone to use.

Second, I developed software that aids in the process of working with evolutionary information.  The evolutionary history of a group of organisms is often represented using a “phylogenetic tree”, a kind of data structure that provides precise information about how organisms are related to one another and how different they are from each other.  Many kinds of scientific questions in biology require manipulating phylogenetic trees with software.  For these tasks, most scientists prefer working with high-level programming languages (R and Python are especially popular), and although there are good software tools available in these languages for working with phylogenetic trees, they typically are not suitable for working with very large trees, either because they use too much computer memory or because they are too slow, or often, both.  The software I developed for working with phylogenetic trees interfaces with the Python programming language and is user friendly, but it is orders of magnitude faster than existing Python-based tools and also uses substantially less memory.  This will make it possible for researchers to compute with trees that have tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands, or even millions of nodes.  This software is also freely available.  It is still in active development, and I hope to have a feature-complete version released within the next year.

Third, I worked on developing a use-case for applying the new technologies described above.  For this, I focused on a family of flies called Sarcophagidae, commonly known as “flesh flies”.  These flies are especially interesting insects because they include a large number of species and they are incredibly diverse in terms of their feeding habits and relationships with other animals.  Thus, they represent an excellent group of insects for investigating questions about evolution and diversity.  During the course of my project, I examined thousands of flesh fly specimens from major entomological collections, and I gathered a large quantity of natural history data from these specimens.  Some of these data have already been curated and published, and, once the software tools described above are fully complete, I intend to use all of these data to better understand the evolutionary processes that shape insect ecological diversity.

Finally, as part of this project, I also received valuable training in a number of areas, including data modeling, knowledge representation techniques, and modern methods for generating and working with genetic data for generating phylogenetic trees.  In addition, I spent considerable time on education and outreach activities, including teaching about the topics described above and general computational methods to university students, mentoring undergraduate researchers, and delivering educational programming about insects to public school students.
